abstract: This text discusses the importance of a physiological change called smoltification in juvenile salmonids, which enables them to survive in seawater. One key aspect of this transformation is an increase in the activity of a specific enzyme, gill Na+, K+ ATPase (NKA), that helps maintain osmotic balance and increases salinity tolerance. Researchers have used NKA activity as a measure to assess the readiness of different populations of salmonids for seawater migration. For instance, hatchery fish typically exhibit lower NKA activity compared to their wild counterparts, which indicates that hatchery fish may be less prepared for the saltwater transition and face higher mortality risk when exposed to seawater. Understanding these differences is crucial as it can inform conservation efforts and improve the efficiency of salmonid aquaculture.
description:
In this text, the focus is on the physiological changes that occur during the parr-smolt transformation in juvenile salmonids, specifically regarding the increased activity of gill Na+, K+ ATPase (NKA) enzyme as a key factor enabling survival in seawater.

The process begins with the initiation of smoltification, where juveniles undergo morphological, behavioral, and physiological changes for adaptation to ocean environments. One significant physiological adjustment is the augmented activity of NKA enzyme within the gills (Folmar and Dickhoff 1980; Hoar 1988). This enzyme plays a crucial role in maintaining osmotic balance by facilitating the extrusion of NaCl across the gills (Hoar 1988; Evans et al. 2005).

By enhancing NKA activity, juvenile salmonids develop improved saltwater tolerance, which is essential for their survival upon entering seawater environments (Hoar 1988). This adaptation enables the fish to cope with the increased salt concentration and potential stressors present in marine habitats.

Several studies have utilized NKA activity measurements as an indicator of osmoregulatory readiness for saltwater entry among hatchery-raised versus natural origin salmonids (Shrimpton et al. 1994). Hatchery fish, due to lower gill NKA activity levels compared to their wild counterparts, are less prepared for the physiological demands of seawater emigration (Shrimpton et al. 1994). Consequently, hatchery fish experience higher mortality rates under saltwater stress conditions than wild conspecifics (Flagg and Smith 1982), further emphasizing the importance of proper NKA activity for successful smoltification and ocean adaptation.
